elements.content: To explore the influence of six structurally different polycarboxylate ligands H2L1 to H4L6 in the system Zn(II)/btmx, six coordination polymers, formulated as [Zn(btmx)(L1)] n (1), {[Zn(btmx)(L2)]·2H2O} n (2), {[Zn(btmx)(L3)]·1.5H2O} n (3), [Zn(btmx)(L4)] n (4), {[Zn4(btmx)3(L5)4(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (5), and [Zn(btmx)(H2L6)] n (6), have been obtained under similar conditions (btmx = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene, H2L1 = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L2 = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L3 = 1,3-adamantanedicarboxylic acid, H2L4 = 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid, H2L5 = 4,4′-oxidibenzoic acid, and H4L6 = 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylic acid). The structure determination reveals that complexes 1 and 4 are two-dimensional (2D) layered networks and exhibit typical (4,4) topological nets. Complex 2 shows an undulating 2D (4,4)-network with 2-fold interpenetration. Complex 3 possesses a three-dimensional (3D) 3-fold interpenetrating 4-connected framework of 66-dia topology. Both 5 and 6 have different 3D interpenetrated motifs generated by 2D → 3D interpenetration. Complex 5 belongs to a 3D framework built from the interpenetration of 2D bilayers in an inclined mode, while 6 involves a parallel interpenetration between the adjacent 2D (4,4) layers. This work markedly indicates that the effect of polycarboxylate ligands is significant in the construction of these networks.

elements.content: A series of Zn(II)/btmx coordination polymers with different structures have been isolated through varying polycarboxylate ligands (btmx = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene). This work markedly indicates that polycarboxylate ligands have a great influence on the architectures of coordination polymers and can be used as a tool to tune structures.

elements.content: In recent years, great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the crystal engineering of coordination polymers due to their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, nonlinear optics and catalysis as well as their aesthetic frameworks. The rapid development of crystal engineering is inevitable to involve the rational design and preparation of crystalline solid material with peculiar topology and desired functions. Up to now, many synthetic approaches have been applied to construct desired and attractive coordination polymers. Generally, the effective strategy for the assembly of desired crystalline products is to use metal centers with suitable geometry and connectivity as the nodes and elaborately designed organic spacers as linkers. Although remarkable progress has been made on the theoretical research and practical manipulation in such a self-assembly reaction, it is still a big problem to predict the exact structures of coordination polymers because of various factors, such as central metal ions, metal–ligand ratio, solvents, temperature, pH value, the nature of the anions and templates. Among them, organic carboxylate anions are extremely important because they can control and adjust the structures of coordination polymers in a monoligand system, even in a two-ligand system. For example, some groups altered carboxylate ligands in a two-ligand system in order to obtain different dimensional architectures ranged from one- to three-dimensional (1D to 3D), and others also gained a series of two-ligand networks with various degrees of interpenetration through manipulating the organic carboxylate anions. However, the systematic investigation of the role of the carboxylate anions in the construction of two-ligand frameworks is not well understood and not conclusive. Therefore, the development of a comprehensive research program in this topic is very necessary.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the crystal engineering of coordination polymers due to their potential applications in ion exchange, gas storage, nonlinear optics and catalysis as well as their aesthetic frameworks. The rapid development of crystal engineering is inevitable to involve the rational design and preparation of crystalline solid material with peculiar topology and desired functions. Up to now, many synthetic approaches have been applied to construct desired and attractive coordination polymers. Generally, the effective strategy for the assembly of desired crystalline products is to use metal centers with suitable geometry and connectivity as the nodes and elaborately designed organic spacers as linkers. Although remarkable progress has been made on the theoretical research and practical manipulation in such a self-assembly reaction, it is still a big problem to predict the exact structures of coordination polymers because of various factors, such as central metal ions, metal-ligand ratio, solvents, temperature, pH value, the nature of the anions and templates. Among them, organic carboxylate anions are extremely important because they can control and adjust the structures of coordination polymers in a monoligand system, even in a two-ligand system. For example, some groups altered carboxylate ligands in a two-ligand system in order to obtain different dimensional architectures ranged from one- to three-dimensional (1D to 3D), and others also gained a series of two-ligand networks with various degrees of interpenetration through manipulating the organic carboxylate anions. However, the systematic investigation of the role of the carboxylate anions in the construction of two-ligand frameworks is not well understood and not conclusive. Therefore, the development of a comprehensive research program in this topic is very necessary.

elements.content: On the other hand, the flexible bis-triazole ligands have been widely used to build fascinating structures because of their excellent coordinating ability and variable conformations. And, in our previous work, we also found bis-triazole ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene (btmx) is a good candidate for the construction of coordination polymers with interesting architectures. Thus, in this paper, we focused our attention on two-ligand assembly reactions of the flexible bis-triazole ligand btmx together with different carboxylate ligands and Zn(II) salts and made systematic investigations on the impact of carboxylate ligands H2L1 to H4L6 on the structures of the complexes (Scheme ). Six different structural coordination polymers, [Zn(btmx)(L1)] n (1), {[Zn(btmx)(L2)]·2H2O} n (2), {[Zn(btmx)(L3)]·1.5H2O} n (3), [Zn(btmx)(L4)] n (4), {[Zn4(btmx)3(L5)4(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (5), and [Zn(btmx)(H2L6)] n (6), have been obtained under similar conditions (H2L1 = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L2 = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2L3 = 1,3-adamantanedicarboxylic acid, H2L4 = 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid, H2L5 = 4,4′-oxidibenzoic acid and H4L6 = 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenone tetracarboxylic acid). The results reveal that polycarboxylate ligands have a great influence on the architectures of coordination polymers and can be used as a tool to tune structures.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. Ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene (btmx) was prepared according to the literature. IR data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the region of 400–4000 cm–1. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using Cu Kα1 radiation on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 in air.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Characterization

All chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. Ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene (btmx) was prepared according to the literature. IR data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the region of 400-4000 cm-1. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using Cu Kα1 radiation on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 in air.

elements.content: The data of the six complexes were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer (Mo-Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature of 20 ± 1 °C. Absorption corrections were applied by using multiscan program. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by using geometrical restrains. Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for complexes 1–6 are summarized in detail in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in . The thermal stability of the coordination architectures was investigated by TGA experiments (). The phase purity of the bulk crystalline product was further confirmed by the PXRD technique, showing the adequate similarity of the experimental and calculated PXRD patterns ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

The data of the six complexes were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer (Mo-Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature of 20 ± 1 °C. Absorption corrections were applied by using multiscan program. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by using geometrical restrains. Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for complexes 1-6 are summarized in detail in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in . The thermal stability of the coordination architectures was investigated by TGA experiments (). The phase purity of the bulk crystalline product was further confirmed by the PXRD technique, showing the adequate similarity of the experimental and calculated PXRD patterns ().

The results of crystallographic analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one L1, and one btmx ligand. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two btmx ligands. The distances of Zn–O/N bond range from 1.975(4)–2.021(5) Å, which are similar to other Zn-based complexes. Each L1 connects two Zn(II) atoms in a μ-bridging fashion with each carboxylate group in monodentate mode. The btmx ligand bridges two Zn(II) atoms in a trans conformation. The bridged Zn···Zn distances along μ-btmx and μ-L1 are 12.73 Å and 10.29 Å, respectively. Then the Zn(II) atoms are connected by μ-L1 anions associated with μ-btmx ligands resulting in a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) network (Figure b). All the Zn(II) ions in each layer are strictly coplanar. The grid motif (42-membered metallocyclic rings) has the dimension of 10.61 × 20.57 Å (diagonal distances). Furthermore, the adjacent 2D layers in an offset way are arranged into a 3D supramolecular framework by two types of π–π stacking interactions. One exists between the triazole rings with the centroid-to-centroid separation of 3.594 Å, and the other appears between the phenyl rings of btmx with centroid-to-centroid distance of 4.010 Å (). The solvent-accessible volume was calculated by PLATON analysis as 4.0% of the crystal volume (46.8 Å3 out of the 1178.8 Å3 unit cell volume), indicating there is a small void in 1 because of the staggered packing arrangement.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(btmx)(L1)] n  (1)

The results of crystallographic analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one L1, and one btmx ligand. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two btmx ligands. The distances of Zn-O/N bond range from 1.975(4)-2.021(5) Å, which are similar to other Zn-based complexes. Each L1 connects two Zn(II) atoms in a μ-bridging fashion with each carboxylate group in monodentate mode. The btmx ligand bridges two Zn(II) atoms in a trans conformation. The bridged Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances along μ-btmx and μ-L1 are 12.73 Å and 10.29 Å, respectively. Then the Zn(II) atoms are connected by μ-L1 anions associated with μ-btmx ligands resulting in a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) network (Figure b). All the Zn(II) ions in each layer are strictly coplanar. The grid motif (42-membered metallocyclic rings) has the dimension of 10.61 × 20.57 Å (diagonal distances). Furthermore, the adjacent 2D layers in an offset way are arranged into a 3D supramolecular framework by two types of π-π stacking interactions. One exists between the triazole rings with the centroid-to-centroid separation of 3.594 Å, and the other appears between the phenyl rings of btmx with centroid-to-centroid distance of 4.010 Å (). The solvent-accessible volume was calculated by PLATON analysis as 4.0% of the crystal volume (46.8 Å3 out of the 1178.8 Å3 unit cell volume), indicating there is a small void in 1 because of the staggered packing arrangement.

elements.content: To study the influence of the carboxylate positions on the complex structures, H2L2 was selected to react with Zn(CH3COO)2·6H2O under similar synthetic conditions, and a new complex 2 was obtained. Although complex 2 as well as 1 shows the same 2D (4,4) grid-like layers, 2 displays a 2-fold parallel interpenetrating framework. The asymmetric unit of complex 2 consists of one Zn(II) atom, two half L2 anions, one btmx ligand, and two lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is also coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L2 ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two btmx ligands to constitute a tetrahedral geometry. The Zn–N/O bond lengths are in the range of 1.958(3)–2.035(3) Å, which are similar to those of 1. Each kind of L2 also connects two Zn(II) atoms in a bis-monodentate mode, and btmx possesses the trans conformation linking two Zn(II) ions. The bridged Zn···Zn distance along μ-btmx is 13.20 Å, and two different Zn···Zn distances along μ-L2 are 10.93 Å and 10.94 Å, respectively. Then the Zn(II) atoms are connected by μ-L2 anions and μ-btmx ligands giving rise to a 4-connected 2D corrugated layered structure with a 44-sql topology (Figure b). Within each layer, two kinds of parallelograms with diagonal distances of 10.54 × 21.83 Å and 16.90 × 17.39 Å are observed. The dihedral angle between these two types of parallelograms is 116.1°. The large void space of the 2D grid is effectively filled via the interpenetration of another independent grid to form a 2-fold parallel interpenetrating net (Figure c). {[Cd(tp)(bpt)(H2O)]2·1.5DMF·H2O} n (bpt = bis(4-pyridyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole and tp = terephthalic acid) and {[Zn(tp)(2,6-bip)]·2H2O} n (2,6-bip = 2,6-bis(imidazole-1-yl)pyridine) were two relevant examples with 2-fold interpenetration similar to that in 2. The solvent-accessible volume in 2 is 55.9 Å3, equal to 4.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the PLATON program.

elements.content: Furthermore, the adjacent interpenetrating layers are held together by π–π stacking interactions to afford a 3D supramolecular framework. There are also two types of π–π stacking interactions. One exists between the triazole rings with the centroid-to-centroid separation of 3.985 Å, and the other appears between the phenyl ring of L2 and triazole ring of btmx with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.577 Å. Additionally, the hydrogen bonding interactions between the free water molecules and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the L2 (O5···O2 = 2.854 Å, O6···O2 = 2.883 Å and O5···O4 = 2.749 Å) stabilize the 3D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: When H2L3 was introduced in place of the rigid ligand H2L1, compound 3 was obtained, which exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating net with 66-dia topology. X-ray crystallography reveals that there is half of Zn(II) atom, half of btmx ligand, half of L3, and three-quarters lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 3. The metal center also possesses a tetrahedral geometry with ZnO2N2 coordination environment, being linked to two oxygen atoms from L3 ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two ligands btmx (Figure a). The Zn–N/O bond lengths vary from 1.956(7) to 2.024(5) Å. Each btmx ligand adopts a trans conformation and links two Zn(II) atoms to form a 1D wave-like chain (Zn–btmx chain) along the a-axis with an adjacent Zn···Zn separation of 13.9216 Å (). The L3 ligand bridges the adjacent Zn(II) atoms in bis-monodentate coordinated mode to generate an infinite 1D zigzag chain (Zn–L3 chain) along the b-axis with the Zn···Zn distance of 9.3870 Å (). The combination of 1D chains of Zn–btmx and Zn–L3 gives rise to a 3D structure (Figure b). Topological analysis of this compound reveals that it is a 4-connected net with 66-dia topology, if the Zn(II) ions are regarded as 4-connected nodes, and ligands btmx and L3 are considered as connectors. Three these nets interweave in parallel to generate a 3-fold interpenetrating structure (3D → 3D parallel) (Figure c). It is isostructural with {[Co(btmx)(1,3,5-HBTC)]·2H2O} n (1,3,5-H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), which has been recently reported by our group. Interestingly, even with the interpenetration, complex 3 still has the solvent-accessible volume of the channels about 267.7 Å3 in the unit cell, which accounts for 9.3% of the total cell volume as calculated by the PLATON program. In addition, hydrogen bonding interactions (O4···O5 = 2.898 Å and O6···O5 = 2.761 Å) contained in this structure presumably help to further reinforce the 3D framework.

elements.content: Compared with the former complexes 1–3, the flexible H2L4 ligand was introduced to investigate the role of flexible dicarboxylate ligand in the formation of metal-triazole polymers, and complex 4 was synthesized. Complex 4 is isomorphous with 1. Nevertheless, some differences exist between the two complexes. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one Zn atom, one L4 anion, and two half btmx ligands. Two types of parallelograms are present in the 2D grid-like structure (Figure b). The type of parallelograms with smaller areas consists of dimensions of 11.73 × 22.02 Å with angles of 55.94° and 124.1°, whereas those of larger ones are 12.38 × 22.56 Å with angles of 57.15° and 122.9°. The sheet in 4 is corrugated, reflecting from a dihedral angle of 113.1° between the two types of polygons. Further, the sheets arrange in an offset way with the grid of each layer occupied by groups from the adjacent ones (Figure c). So, this structure has no solvent accessible volume. And there are no obvious π–π stacking interactions in 4.

elements.content: When the long and flexible polycarboxylate ligand H2L5 was used, a 3D entangled architecture constructed by 2D catenated networks with unprecedented topology was isolated. The asymmetric unit of 5 is composed of two crystallographically distinct Zn atoms, one and a half btmx ligands, two L5 ligands, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Zn1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two btmx ligands and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L5 ligands. The Zn2 atom also adopts a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, defined by one nitrogen atom of one btmx ligand, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L5 ligands, and one coordinated water molecule. There are two kinds of L5 ligands. Each kind of L5 connects Zn(II) atoms using its two carboxylate groups in a bis-monodentate coordination mode. As a result, the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are connected by the two kinds of L5 ligands to afford two 1D chains with the same adjacent Zn···Zn distance of 14.6915 Å, respectively (Figure b). Furthermore, two such 1D chains are bridged by btmx ligands to generate a 2D bilayer structure (Figure c). The ligands btmx take two distinct conformations (cis and trans) with different Zn···Zn distances of 8.6306 and 15.6518 Å.

When the long and flexible polycarboxylate ligand H2L5 was used, a 3D entangled architecture constructed by 2D catenated networks with unprecedented topology was isolated. The asymmetric unit of 5 is composed of two crystallographically distinct Zn atoms, one and a half btmx ligands, two L5 ligands, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Zn1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two btmx ligands and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L5 ligands. The Zn2 atom also adopts a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, defined by one nitrogen atom of one btmx ligand, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L5 ligands, and one coordinated water molecule. There are two kinds of L5 ligands. Each kind of L5 connects Zn(II) atoms using its two carboxylate groups in a bis-monodentate coordination mode. As a result, the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are connected by the two kinds of L5 ligands to afford two 1D chains with the same adjacent Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 14.6915 Å, respectively (Figure b). Furthermore, two such 1D chains are bridged by btmx ligands to generate a 2D bilayer structure (Figure c). The ligands btmx take two distinct conformations (cis and trans) with different Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances of 8.6306 and 15.6518 Å.

elements.content: From the topological point of view, if the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are regarded as 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, and ligands btmx and L5 are considered as linkers, the 2D structure of 5 can be described as a (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (42·6·83)(82·10) (Figure d). The open void space within the 2D network is minimized by the interpenetration of another two identical 2D networks in an inclined fashion, with each layer catenated by two others (“above” and “below”), to produce a 2D → 3D interpenetrating network. The void volume of 939.4 Å3 (8.9%) is also left after interpenetration. Furthermore, the weak π–π stacking interactions are observed between the phenyl rings of L5 (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.0 Å) as well as phenyl rings of L5 and the triazole rings (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.1 Å), which stabilize the structure. The structural stability is also provided by hydrogen bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the L5 (O11···O7 = 2.654 Å).

elements.content: When H2L5 was replaced by H4L6, a new compound 6 was obtained. The structure of 6 contains one kind of Zn(II) atom, two kinds of unique btmx ligands, and one kind of H2L6 anion. The tetrahedral arrangement {ZnN2O2} around the Zn(II) atom is completed by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two H2L6 anions and two nitrogen atoms from the btmx ligands (Figure a). The Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges. Each Zn(II) atom is linked by carboxylate groups of H2L6 ligand in bis-monodentate coordination mode to form a 1D infinite chain with a Zn···Zn distance of 14.61 (3) Å (). The 1D zigzag chain is also formed by the two kinds of trans-conformational btmx ligands and Zn(II) with a Zn···Zn separation of 14.54 and 15.30 Å, respectively (). These 1D chains are interlinked together to generate an undulating or corrugated 2D 44-sql network with a point symbol (44·62). Two types of parallelograms in this uninodal 2D network are also present (Figure b), which have large dimensions of 16.15 × 25.17 Å and 18.15 × 22.80 Å (diagonal distances), respectively. The dihedral angle between these two types of polygons is 108.3°, which is smaller than that in 2, indicating that 6 is more undulating than 2. So, the corrugated layer is further catenated to the adjacent (“upper” and “lower”) layers in a parallel fashion to give an overall 2D → 3D polycatenated network (Figure c). Because of the polycatenation, no solvent accessible volume is found in the structure. To the best of our knowledge, only a limited number of examples of 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation with (4,4) nets have been reported to date. The crystal structure of complex 6 is further strengthened through hydrogen bonding interactions between the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4···O3 = 2.684(3) Å and O5···O6 = 2.609(4) Å).

elements.content: The conditions to synthesize all these six compounds are almost the same except that polycarboxylate ligands are different, from H2L1 to H4L6. Under the influences of these polycarboxylate ligands, compounds 1–6 illustrate a series of different networks based on Zn(II) nodes. Generally, the role of carboxylate anions can be explained in terms of their differences in the positions of the carboxylate groups, the lengths of the spacer, the flexible abilities, and the spacer groups of the carboxylate anions. Compounds 1 and 2 show the effects of carboxylate positions on the structures of their complexes. Although both L1 and L2 act as dicarboxylate anions with the rigid benzene ring spacers, the two carboxylate groups of L1 are located in the 1,3-positions of benzene ring, whereas those of L2 are in the 1,4-positions. Consequently, 1 shows a 2D layered 44-sql network, whereas 2 has an undulating 2D 44-sql network with 2-fold interpenetration. Obviously, the position discrimination of the carboxylateligand leads to the structural difference of 1 and 2. Complexes 3 and 4 imply the influence of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands on the resulting frameworks. Although both H2L3 and H2L4 are based on adamantane spacers, the length and flexibility of the spacers are different. H2L3 is a rigid ligand, while H2L4 ligand possesses flexibility owing to the presence of the −CH2– spacer, which allows the two carboxylate groups to bridge the metals from different directions. As a result, 3 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating dia net, whereas 4 shows a 2D 44-sql network. When the long flexible polycarboxylate ligands H2L5 and H4L6 were introduced in the syntheses of 5 and 6, respectively, two 2D → 3D interpenetrating networks with distinct topologies were obtained. The two carboxylate groups of H2L5 are located in 4,4′-positions of two benzene rings linked by an -O- group, while the four carboxylate groups of H4L6 are located in 3,3′,4,4′-positions of two benzene rings linked by a CO group. Although H4L6 is a tetracarboxylate ligand, only two carboxylate groups of 4,4′-positions are deprotonated. Thus, H4L6 plays the role of a dicarboxylate ligand. The employment of H2L5 gives a (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (42·6·83)(82·10), while the incompletely deprotonated H4L6 provides a 3D framework constructed from 2D 44-sql layers by parallel polycatenation. Obviously, the structural difference of compounds 5 and 6 is mainly attributed to the effect of the spacer group of the carboxylate ligands. Comparing 2 and 6, we found that both 2 and 6 are 2D 44-sql networks with interpenetration. But complex 6 has the higher dimensionality than 2. This is because of the long polycarboxylate anion H2L6 in 6. Complex 6 demonstrates that the use of the long polycarboxylate anion H2L6 is advisable to generate the 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation network. It is interesting that complexes 1 and 4 have similar 44-sql networks, but they do not form the interpenetrating networks like 2 and 6. This may be because of the smaller angle of two carboxylate groups in H2L1 and the flexibility of spacial tendency with less steric hindrance in H2L4. The different structures of complexes 1 and 3 also indicate that the spacers of polycarboxylate ligands have a great effect on two-ligand networks.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Complex Structures

The conditions to synthesize all these six compounds are almost the same except that polycarboxylate ligands are different, from H2L1 to H4L6. Under the influences of these polycarboxylate ligands, compounds 1-6 illustrate a series of different networks based on Zn(II) nodes. Generally, the role of carboxylate anions can be explained in terms of their differences in the positions of the carboxylate groups, the lengths of the spacer, the flexible abilities, and the spacer groups of the carboxylate anions. Compounds 1 and 2 show the effects of carboxylate positions on the structures of their complexes. Although both L1 and L2 act as dicarboxylate anions with the rigid benzene ring spacers, the two carboxylate groups of L1 are located in the 1,3-positions of benzene ring, whereas those of L2 are in the 1,4-positions. Consequently, 1 shows a 2D layered 44-sql network, whereas 2 has an undulating 2D 44-sql network with 2-fold interpenetration. Obviously, the position discrimination of the carboxylateligand leads to the structural difference of 1 and 2. Complexes 3 and 4 imply the influence of the spacer length and flexibility of the carboxylate ligands on the resulting frameworks. Although both H2L3 and H2L4 are based on adamantane spacers, the length and flexibility of the spacers are different. H2L3 is a rigid ligand, while H2L4 ligand possesses flexibility owing to the presence of the -CH2- spacer, which allows the two carboxylate groups to bridge the metals from different directions. As a result, 3 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating dia net, whereas 4 shows a 2D 44-sql network. When the long flexible polycarboxylate ligands H2L5 and H4L6 were introduced in the syntheses of 5 and 6, respectively, two 2D → 3D interpenetrating networks with distinct topologies were obtained. The two carboxylate groups of H2L5 are located in 4,4'-positions of two benzene rings linked by an -O- group, while the four carboxylate groups of H4L6 are located in 3,3',4,4'-positions of two benzene rings linked by a CO group. Although H4L6 is a tetracarboxylate ligand, only two carboxylate groups of 4,4'-positions are deprotonated. Thus, H4L6 plays the role of a dicarboxylate ligand. The employment of H2L5 gives a (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (42⋅6⋅83)(82⋅10), while the incompletely deprotonated H4L6 provides a 3D framework constructed from 2D 44-sql layers by parallel polycatenation. Obviously, the structural difference of compounds 5 and 6 is mainly attributed to the effect of the spacer group of the carboxylate ligands. Comparing 2 and 6, we found that both 2 and 6 are 2D 44-sql networks with interpenetration. But complex 6 has the higher dimensionality than 2. This is because of the long polycarboxylate anion H2L6 in 6. Complex 6 demonstrates that the use of the long polycarboxylate anion H2L6 is advisable to generate the 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation network. It is interesting that complexes 1 and 4 have similar 44-sql networks, but they do not form the interpenetrating networks like 2 and 6. This may be because of the smaller angle of two carboxylate groups in H2L1 and the flexibility of spacial tendency with less steric hindrance in H2L4. The different structures of complexes 1 and 3 also indicate that the spacers of polycarboxylate ligands have a great effect on two-ligand networks.

elements.content: In summary, the self-assembly reactions of the flexible bis-triazole ligand and a series of polycarboxylate ligands with Zn(II) cations produce six diverse coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complexes 1 and 4 have 2D similar layered networks with typical (4,4) topological nets using polycarboxylate ligands H2L1 and H2L4. While complexes 2 and 3 have 2D → 2D and 3D → 3D parallel interpenetration with the rigid polycarboxylate ligands H2L2 and H2L3, respectively, and 5 and 6 are 2D → 3D interpenetrating networks with different topologies with the long flexible polycarboxylate ligands H2L5 and H4L6, respectively. This investigation has demonstrated that the positions of the carboxylate groups, the length and flexibility of polycarboxylate ligands play significant roles in determining the structures of coordination polymers. Therefore, the networks could be modified by the nature of polycarboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the self-assembly reactions of the flexible bis-triazole ligand and a series of polycarboxylate ligands with Zn(II) cations produce six diverse coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complexes 1 and 4 have 2D similar layered networks with typical (4,4) topological nets using polycarboxylate ligands H2L1 and H2L4. While complexes 2 and 3 have 2D → 2D and 3D → 3D parallel interpenetration with the rigid polycarboxylate ligands H2L2 and H2L3, respectively, and 5 and 6 are 2D → 3D interpenetrating networks with different topologies with the long flexible polycarboxylate ligands H2L5 and H4L6, respectively. This investigation has demonstrated that the positions of the carboxylate groups, the length and flexibility of polycarboxylate ligands play significant roles in determining the structures of coordination polymers. Therefore, the networks could be modified by the nature of polycarboxylate ligands.

cln_elements.content:
Compared with the former complexes 1–3, the flexible H2L4 ligand was introduced to investigate the role of flexible dicarboxylate ligand in the formation of metal-triazole polymers, and complex 4 was synthesized. Complex 4 is isomorphous with 1. Nevertheless, some differences exist between the two complexes. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one Zn atom, one L4 anion, and two half btmx ligands. Two types of parallelograms are present in the 2D grid-like structure (Figure b). The type of parallelograms with smaller areas consists of dimensions of 11.73 × 22.02 Å with angles of 55.94° and 124.1°, whereas those of larger ones are 12.38 × 22.56 Å with angles of 57.15° and 122.9°. The sheet in 4 is corrugated, reflecting from a dihedral angle of 113.1° between the two types of polygons. Further, the sheets arrange in an offset way with the grid of each layer occupied by groups from the adjacent ones (Figure c). So, this structure has no solvent accessible volume. And there are no obvious π–π stacking interactions in 4.

From the topological point of view, if the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are regarded as 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, and ligands btmx and L5 are considered as linkers, the 2D structure of 5 can be described as a (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (42·6·83)(82·10) (Figure d). The open void space within the 2D network is minimized by the interpenetration of another two identical 2D networks in an inclined fashion, with each layer catenated by two others (“above” and “below”), to produce a 2D → 3D interpenetrating network. The void volume of 939.4 Å3 (8.9%) is also left after interpenetration. Furthermore, the weak π–π stacking interactions are observed between the phenyl rings of L5 (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.0 Å) as well as phenyl rings of L5 and the triazole rings (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.1 Å), which stabilize the structure. The structural stability is also provided by hydrogen bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the L5 (O11···O7 = 2.654 Å).

Crystal Structure of [Zn(btmx)(L4)] n  (4)

Compared with the former complexes 1-3, the flexible H2L4 ligand was introduced to investigate the role of flexible dicarboxylate ligand in the formation of metal-triazole polymers, and complex 4 was synthesized. Complex 4 is isomorphous with 1. Nevertheless, some differences exist between the two complexes. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one Zn atom, one L4 anion, and two half btmx ligands. Two types of parallelograms are present in the 2D grid-like structure (Figure b). The type of parallelograms with smaller areas consists of dimensions of 11.73 × 22.02 Å with angles of 55.94° and 124.1°, whereas those of larger ones are 12.38 × 22.56 Å with angles of 57.15° and 122.9°. The sheet in 4 is corrugated, reflecting from a dihedral angle of 113.1° between the two types of polygons. Further, the sheets arrange in an offset way with the grid of each layer occupied by groups from the adjacent ones (Figure c). So, this structure has no solvent accessible volume. And there are no obvious π-π stacking interactions in 4.

From the topological point of view, if the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are regarded as 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, and ligands btmx and L5 are considered as linkers, the 2D structure of 5 can be described as a (3,4)-connected net with the point symbol of (42⋅6⋅83)(82⋅10) (Figure d). The open void space within the 2D network is minimized by the interpenetration of another two identical 2D networks in an inclined fashion, with each layer catenated by two others ("above" and "below"), to produce a 2D → 3D interpenetrating network. The void volume of 939.4 Å3 (8.9%) is also left after interpenetration. Furthermore, the weak π-π stacking interactions are observed between the phenyl rings of L5 (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.0 Å) as well as phenyl rings of L5 and the triazole rings (the centroid-to-centroid separation of about 4.1 Å), which stabilize the structure. The structural stability is also provided by hydrogen bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the L5 (O11⋅⋅⋅O7 = 2.654 Å).
